natural solution: Notice that problem has three pairs of the form $\sin \theta + \sin(\pi - \theta).$  The sum-to-product formula yields \begin{align} \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{5\pi}{12} \\

&= 2 \cos \frac{\pi}{12}. \end{align}Applying the sum-to-product formula once more yields \begin{align} & \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = pi / 12"
shows  "sin x + sin (3*x) + sin (5*x) + sin (7*x) + sin (9*x) + sin (11*x) = sqrt 2 + sqrt 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute:
\[
\sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12}.
\] The final Answer is \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}
 ### Proof
 Notice that problem has three pairs of the form $\sin \theta + \sin(\pi - \theta).$  The sum-to-product formula yields \begin{align} \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{5\pi}{12} \\
 &= 2 \cos \frac{5\pi}{12}, \\ \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{4} \\ &= \sqrt{2}, \\ \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{12} \\
 &= 2 \cos \frac{\pi}{12}. \end{align}Applying the sum-to-product formula once more yields \begin{align} & \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} \\
 &= \sqrt{2} + 2 \Big(\cos \frac{5\pi}{12} + \cos \frac{\pi}{12} \Big) \\ &= \sqrt{2} + 4 \cos \frac{\pi}{4} \cos \frac{\pi}{6} \\ &= \sqrt{2} + 4 \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = pi / 12"
shows  "sin x + sin (3*x) + sin (5*x) + sin (7*x) + sin (9*x) + sin (11*x) = sqrt 2 + sqrt 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of the sine of $\pi/12$ and the sine of its multiples (up to the 11th multiple) such that the sum equals $\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = pi / 12"
shows  "sin x + sin (3 * x) + sin (5 * x) + sin (7 * x) + sin (9 * x) + sin (11 * x) = sqrt 2 + sqrt 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute:
\[
\sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12}.
\] The final Answer is \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}
 ### Proof
 Notice that problem has three pairs of the form $\sin \theta + \sin(\pi - \theta).$  The sum-to-product formula yields \begin{align} \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{5\pi}{12} \\
 &= 2 \cos \frac{5\pi}{12}, \\ \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{4} \\ &= \sqrt{2}, \\ \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{12} \\
 &= 2 \cos \frac{\pi}{12}. \end{align}Applying the sum-to-product formula once more yields \begin{align} & \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} \\
 &= \sqrt{2} + 2 \Big(\cos \frac{5\pi}{12} + \cos \frac{\pi}{12} \Big) \\ &= \sqrt{2} + 4 \cos \frac{\pi}{4} \cos \frac{\pi}{6} \\ &= \sqrt{2} + 4 \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = pi / 12"
shows  "sin x + sin (3 * x) + sin (5 * x) + sin (7 * x) + sin (9 * x) + sin (11 * x) = sqrt 2 + sqrt 6"
 proof-

(* ### Problem

\[
\sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12}.
\] The final Answer is \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}

 Notice that problem has three pairs of the form $\sin \theta + \sin(\pi - \theta).$  The sum-to-product formula yields \begin{align} \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{5\pi}{12} \\
 &= 2 \cos \frac{5\pi}{12}, \\ \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{4} \\ &= \sqrt{2}, \\ \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{12} \\
 &= 2 \cos \frac{\pi}{12}. \end{align}Applying the sum-to-product formula once more yields \begin{align} & \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} \\

 *)

theorem

(* ### Problem

\[

\] The final Answer is \sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}

 Notice that problem has three pairs of the form $\sin \theta + \sin(\pi - \theta).$  The sum-to-product formula yields \begin{align} \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} &= 2 \sin \frac{\pi}{2} \cos \frac{5\pi}{12} \\

 &= 2 \cos \frac{\pi}{12}. \end{align}Applying the sum-to-product formula once more yields \begin{align} & \sin \frac{\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{3\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{5\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{7\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{9\pi}{12} + \sin \frac{11\pi}{12} \\
 &= \sqrt{2} + 2 \Big(\cos \frac{5\pi}{12} + \cos \frac{\pi}{12} \Big) \\ &= \sqrt{2} + 4 \cos \frac{\pi}{4} \cos \frac{\pi}{6} \\ &= \sqrt{2} + 4 \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \\ &= \boxed{\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

a_9.informal problem: Calculate the sum of the values of the function $\sin(\frac{\pi}{12}x)$ at $x = 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11$. The final answer is $\sqrt{2} + \sqrt{6}$.
